item.dc:creator: nasaba
item.excerpt:encoded: For more advanced players, Vincent suggests moving on to straight pigment (MAC or even OCC's Pure Cosmetic Pigments). With the added moisture, they'll become easier to layer with other products.

item.title: wet-to-dry-dual-intensity-eyeshadow-makeup-5
item.dc:creator: nasaba
item.excerpt:encoded: The joy of a wet-to-dry is you have to get it right amount of product loaded up, and then it blends itself.

item.title: wet-to-dry-dual-intensity-eyeshadow-makeup-6
item.dc:creator: nasaba
item.excerpt:encoded: Do not, repeat, do not put eye drops, water, or any other sort of liquid directly on your eye shadow. This'll screw up your product for later use.

item.title: wet-to-dry-dual-intensity-eyeshadow-makeup-7
item.dc:creator: nasaba
item.excerpt:encoded: This all depends on exactly what you want to do. "Mind the resistance," Vincent says, particularly if you're looking for uniform color across the lid. "I tend to recommend a blender brush, which is the brush that looks like a feather duster.

item.title: citi-bike-hair-1
item.dc:creator: nasaba
item.excerpt:encoded: I ride a Citi Bike every day—to my office, cross-town for after work drinks, to Brooklyn to visit my brother.

item.title: citi-bike-hair-3
item.dc:creator: nasaba
item.excerpt:encoded: 'm all over it. I soon discovered that in addition to being my favored form of public transportation, riding a Citi Bike (or any bike) is also the perfect opportunity for a low-maintenance beauty person like myself to fake the look of "doing my hair."

item.title: citi-bike-hair-4
item.dc:creator: nasaba
item.excerpt:encoded: Here's what I do: I wash and condition my hair, and then, while it's still wet, I take a wide tooth comb and run it through.

item.title: citi-bike-hair-8
item.dc:creator: nasaba
item.excerpt:encoded: I have naturally curly hair, but if I comb it, the curls turn into waves. Then I twirl my hair (still wet) up into a bun and clip it. At this point, I let my hair dry naturally. Sometimes I do this at night, sometimes early in the morning.

item.title: 'The Jonathan Ross Show - Madonna Special' TV Programme, London, Britain. - 14 Mar 2015
item.dc:creator: nasaba
item.excerpt:encoded:
EXCLUSIVE - EDITORIAL USE ONLY / NO MERCHANDISING
Mandatory Credit: Photo by Dave Hogan/Hotsauce/REX (4462483c)
Jonathan Ross and Madonna
'The Jonathan Ross Show - Madonna Special' TV Programme, London, Britain. - 14 Mar 2015
The pop legend appears in a very special episode of The Jonathan Ross Show, which will air in mid-March, talking for the first time about her fall at the recent Brit Awards and her thoughts on her children taking drugs.
The Jonathan Ross Show Madonna Special will broadcast on ITV on Saturday March 14. The next episode (Saturday February 28) features Sigourney Weaver, Thierry Henry, Martin Clunes, Kanye West and Tracey Emin, airing at 9.40pm on ITV1.

I guess we have a good balance.”

item.excerpt:encoded: Jessica Alba turns 34 on Tuesday, and we're celebrating with a look back at her best bikini pictures.

item.title: Jessica-Alba-Wallpaper-48
item.dc:creator: nasaba
item.excerpt:encoded: Jessica's been no stranger to the two-piece and looks equally as fantastic in a swimsuit on screen as she does while lounging on the beach. The actress even rocked a bikini just four months after giving birth to her daughter Honor in 2008, and continued to flaunt her tan and toned body after having daughter Haven in 2011.

item.title: jessica-alba-sexy-hd-mobile-722026
item.dc:creator: nasaba
item.excerpt:encoded: Plus, she shows off plenty of PDA with husband Cash Warren on their many trips to St. Barts and Hawaii — we're not sure if their kisses or her many scorching bikini moments are hotter!

item.title: She-Got-Married-19
item.dc:creator: nasaba
item.excerpt:encoded: In 2000, Kim tied the knot with her first husband, Damon Thomas of the music-producing group The Underdogs, in Las Vegas. Damon filed for divorce three years later.

item.title: She-Queen-Closet-Organizing-Scene
item.dc:creator: nasaba
item.excerpt:encoded: There was a time when she could only dream about attending the Met Gala. Years before she made big bucks with endorsement deals, Kim earned her income by revamping closets for Hollywood's elite. "My closet business came about when I was at my godparents' house, Sugar Ray Leonard and his wife, Bernadette," she said in an interview with Player magazine in 2006. "Bernadette's closet was massive and had so much stuff in it. I said to her, 'You really need to clean out your closet.' Well, we spent the whole night doing that." After word about her skills spread, Cindy Crawford, Serena Williams, Nicky Hilton, and Nicole Richie sought her organizing services, and Brandy and Lindsay Lohan counted on her as their personal stylist.

item.title: Her-14th-Birthday-Party-Michael-Jackson-Neverland-Ranch
item.dc:creator: nasaba
item.excerpt:encoded: In an interview with People Magazine in 2009, Kim said she dated one of MJ's nephews in her teen years. One of the perks: celebrating her milestone at the singer's very own amusement park. "That was the most magical place on earth," she said. "When you drove up, there were baby elephants and chimpanzees in overalls, and there was all the rides. It was everything you can possibly imagine. The memories I have from that place will last for the rest of my life."

item.title: She-Attended-All-Girl-Catholic-School
item.dc:creator: nasaba
item.excerpt:encoded: What do the Kardashian sisters have in common with Mia Farrow and Mariska Hargitay? They all went to Marymount High School, where students have to fulfill a requirement of 100 hours of community service before they can graduate. Years after Kim finished school, she reflected on her 1997 yearbook photo. "People say, 'She's had her lips and her nose done.' Look at this photo. Tiny nose, huge lips. My lips look bigger here than they do now," she said.

item.title: Concour d'elegance: Vintage is Elegance
item.dc:creator: Kutswavictor
item.content:encoded: “The best way to look stylish on a budget is to try second-hand, bargain hunting and vintage.” Well that has always been the case at every series of the Concour d’Elegance with a great line-up of vehicles. The 46thannual CBA Africa Concour d’Elegance held at Ngong Racecourse, Nairobi on 25th September was nothing short of sophistication. The event that is organized by the Alfa Romeo Owners Club attracted massive crowd of spectators and car enthusiast, and certainly I wasn’t to be left behind. Concour d’Elegance just as the name suggest means “competition of elegance.” It basically is a competition of prestigious automobiles and motorcycles dating back to the 17th Century - a celebration of history of automobiles. Participants showcased their exceptional machines on the judging ring to give spectators a chance to view and contrast. Despite the vehicles being from the days of yore, the vehicles have been well maintained to fit occasion. On exhibit was the 1950 Jaguar Mark V, the 1961 Volkswagen Karmann Ghia of renowned Dj Adrian Washika, a gleaming red Ducati Motorcycle, the classic 1946 ford, Shortie 1974 mini Morris just to mention a few. Steve Parkison’s snow white Jaguar Mark V won the overall car trophy. The spotless clean car had all it takes to beat its competition. It exterior which was complemented by its rim to the interior which had a the The gleaming red Ducati motorcycle owned by Russel Hughes was regarded the most elegant bike as it won the hearts of the concur spectators. Definitely this is the classiest event on the Kenya Motor Sports Federation calendar and here are picture from the event. Photo Credit: Victor Kutswa

item.title: Yellow Fever: A Film Exploring Colourism (Shadeism)
item.dc:creator: nasaba
item.content:encoded: By virtue of the vast cultural differences between Africa and the west, it could be argued that we share lot in common. Ideally, we in Africa borrow a lot from the west and neglect our very own ways. We claim that if we want to conform to civilization we need to be like west, and in equal measure fail to see ourselves as enough. It has become a common phenomenon that reflects in how we wear our hair, dress, talk and associate. It could easily be assumed that we detest our “inferior” being. Most African girls prefer a light skin tone to a darker one, and, therefore, they neglect the idea of being black, authentic and proud. Some are willing to do whatever it takes to achieve a lighter complexion. They believe that the lighter you are the more you’ll be appreciated. In September 2012, Ng’endo Mukii created a 7-minute, mixed-media documentary animation that details colorism and self-appreciation. The project, which was her thesis at the Royal College of Art in London, combines hand-drawn animation and live performance. It highlights what is believed to be the global standards of beauty. In the film, she shows the will by some dark skinned women to use harmful substances to lighten their skin. In the opening of the film, Ng’endo and her sister are at the Salon. The woman who is braiding her hair is a “mkorogo”, which means “she could only afford enough beauty cream to bleach her hands and face, which are now yellow.” The video which is a narration by Ng’endo details the desire of dark Africans to want to look like the white person. She highlights the effects of colonization - especially how it has influenced people’s perception of beauty. In another scene, Ng’endo engages in a casual conversation with her niece who confesses she is somehow uncomfortable about her dark skin. Her niece admits,” If I was American I would be white, white, white, white, and I love being white.” Ng’endo also questions her mother who believes that her daughters would look much better if their hair was straightened. The award-winning film doesn’t necessary criticize those who make the decision to lighten their skin. No, instead the filmmaker is simply championing for the appreciation of the dark skin. She wants the world to appreciate being African and all that comes with it. Watch “Yellow Fever” below: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5DATFjkueaM

item.title: Anywal Abel: A Three in One Instrument
item.dc:creator: nasaba
item.content:encoded: The most amazing part about this world is that it is filled with intricate, professional music. Nothing beats a properly composed song with ethereal instrumentation. A good number of musical legends assert that a complete musician is one who can play at least one instrument. I believe a brilliant musician is one who can ornately bring together different components of sound to create a masterpiece. Martin Murimi, better known by his stage name Papillon, is one such kind of artiste. It would be fit to refer to him as a gifted, harp virtuoso. Actually, he is capable of making his own instruments and, I have been fortunate enough to witness him play his Anywal Abel. He says the name is Acholi for caring parents. His skill on the three in one instrument (comprising of a harp, percussion and thumb piano) is undeniably  exceptional. Papillon, a protégé of renowned Ayub Ogada, is deep into designing new instruments. The artiste who never let go of his dream to be a fantastic musician from a young age is now more than just that singer. His passion of music has driven him to build his own instrument, which I think is pure genius. The fascinating history of the 8-stringed harps, as detailed in the opening of his first release “ Ayubu,” might not be clear to most of us. However, Papillon takes key interest in the ancient instrument and is able to successfully build the Anywal Abel. Papillon who embraces a lot about culture in his music and style reflects the same in the construction of his instrument. Attached to one end of the instrument is an  African artifact depicting a face. This is the type of instrument you expect to be played in a relaxed, outdoor jam session that celebrates traditional and world music. Complemented by other instruments it certainly gives a soulful feel. The Anywal Abel is indeed an excellent creation built  by an outstanding artist. Check out the "Ayubu" video below. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xJSq8xDTBpA

item.title: About Us
item.dc:creator: nasaba
item.content:encoded: NASABA is an integrative, conceptual platform that details ideas, creative minds and contemporary art. Our goal is to highlight creative excellence experienced in our day to day interaction with society. Our mission is to create, promote, educate and inform through our collaborations with incredible contributors in the society. We acknowledge that our surrounding comprises of incredible situations that can influence how we view things. We also appreciate the will by people to want be self- expressive in order to free their minds form doctrines and conventionalism. The brilliant minds behind the NASABA site are dedicate to communicate to the world in a thought-provoking manner. As we strive to achieve the best content we expect to learn a lot and have plenty of fun while doing it. NASABA is swahili for "dynasty." We strive to bring out the best of different perspectives and create our own realities. NASABA |We Are No Different Either

item.title: Thrift Social 8 Was a Waxprint Affair
item.dc:creator: nasaba
item.content:encoded: Great minds come up with best ideas. But I can tell you from my experience that it takes more than just an idea to actually have a masterpiece. What even makes it intriguing is if you have a supportive community around you. Now, the fashion siblings, Velma Rossa and Papa Petit, more often than not, are likely to be seen sharing photos of themselves - oddly dressed - on their social media accounts. And that's quite the phenomenon. But that's not all they can offer. Behind this spectacular duo is a brilliant concept made of endless ideas. The 2manysiblings went all out to ensure that the Thrift Social 8 would be a success. Yes, they have done this so often, and this time they offered a show better than previously held installments. The show set at Privee in Westlands, Nairobi provided such appropriate space for the attendees to exhibit their best attire. Apart from a few poopers, I apologetically included, revellers arrived dressed in the afternoon's theme - the African Waxprint. Celebrities,fashion designers, photographers, musicians, sportsmen were not left out of the fun. African prints might be assumed to be a major fashion feat, but those present confirmed that it's not as hard at it seems. Props to the siblings for creating memories at the Privee rooftop, as well as for providing great music courtesy of the fashionable Accra-based Dj Steloo, Cosmic Homies' spitter Taio and Mix Master Lenny. I must admit it was an amazing set of electronic, hip-hop music mix put together with an unique smashing of cymbals. Great sound combo. Wearing African prints can be overwhelming, but the siblings make it look easy. They turn every attire into a classical piece, and once you get hooked to their artistic way of life and style you'll likely find yourself thrifting. Photo Credits: Victor Kutswa

item.title: The Crowd-Pleasing, Thought-Provoking Performers
item.dc:creator: nasaba
item.content:encoded: Who runs the stage? I have asked so many "experts" this very question, and I never seem to ever agree with any of them. The Kenyan live performance scene has been tremendous, I must admit. However, I really have to give the top spot to Sarabi who have done justice every time I have seen them perform. Sarabi has always brought nearly superhuman levels of energy to their shows. They have a brilliantly expressive way of playing music without ever losing their chaotic intensity. Yes, I have seen the band perform a couple of times on different stages, and again I recently got the chance to be at the #SARABIExperience held at the Alliance Française. The whole time, the connection with the band was very, very personal. So the band got on stage and kicked off their performance with a blistering rendition of the National anthem, which makes the original limp in comparison – I think. Gradually they managed to whip the audience with hit after hit. The 8- member band entertained with their dramatization, intense dancing and impressive instrumentation. Nelson Mandela, the band's lead vocalist, managed to keep the audience on toes. The outspoken artist strongly advocated for tolerance, love and unity, and was quite vocal against racial profiling. The one thing I adore the most about Sarabi is that they know the right dose of tunes and stories about issues affecting us to whip arenas into a frenzy. They don't take the easy way out. Beyond the contagious energy, the band’s rapport is always lighthearted and fun. This is one act that you shouldn't miss out on. What do you think?  Photo Credits: Kutswa Imboto

item.title: Night Dancers Gets Ghoulish
item.dc:creator: nasaba
item.content:encoded: Halloween is gradually gaining acceptance into our society. Considering the level of cultural appropriation in this country, it wouldn't be a surprise if in the next couple of years it becomes an actual thing. I don't know if mother will really take it when that day actually happens (she really doesn't get it). Anyway, Night Dancer: In The Spirit of Halloween was held over the weekend, and trust me, it was a phenomenon. I think it was genius to have a show celebrating both alternative music and some creepy day. If you think hard about it, it really doesn't add up, but nothing's impossible. If you know anything about Halloween ( I assume that not most of us understand much about the rich, nobled tradition), you at least know that it involves inauthentic costumes and eerie make up with endless possibilities. Well that was the case at Night Dancers. The night was graced with a proper performance line-up from the likes of the amazing EA Wave, UK-based Hednoka, Yellow Light Machine, Cosmic Homies, and Tha Movement. Partygoers were treated to a great set of unconventional music which included live band performances and a crazy deejay set. I am a great fan of live performances, and this is because every show tells its own story. Night Dancers offered a modern choreograpghy, upbeat mood and powerful display. Backed by a full band, artists took the stage in turns. Everybody's favourite Mayonde gave a powerful performance alongside the amazing Tetu Shani. Dressed in a sexy, black swan costume, Marushka of Cosmic Homies gave a robust performance. It almost goes without saying that around such a great crowd is an impressive night full of thrill. The partgoers and performers went all out with their extraordinary costumes. Personally, I was very impressed by one reveller's obvious choice to come dressed as Donald Trump. That was yuge! 😂 The show was absolutely knockout. Revellers not only got to enjoy the great sound, they also got the chance to get innovative with the costumes they showcased. What a night! Photo Credits: Kutswa Imboto

item.title: For The Cleopatra Gifted
item.dc:creator: sammasaku
item.content:encoded: People have distinct perspectives of what beauty really is. Some get carried away by those with long, glossy hair, line-free face and a trim, fit figure. Others prefer curvaceous plus-size models, while others simply adore the fashion and glamour involved. The Affrik Modeling Agency sees beyond fashion & glamour - far much beyond style & beauty.  The agency focuses on uplifting, nurturing and showcasing the feminine gifts bestowed upon ladies. Last weekend the agency hosted one of the biggest modeling/fashion auditions ever in Nairobi. Over 100 models were shortlisted from an intial number of 600 models who had graced the Miss Glamorous 2016/2017 auditions. The brainchild of this initiative, Mr F.K Mwangi, who is also C.E.O of Afrika Nasaha Production is quite the dedicated man. He sees this step as a way of rescuing Kenyan models from swindling modeling agencies that recruit, but in turn exploit and misuse the gifts of these talented beauties. After the shortlisting, the models will be  divided into two categories. The first batch will feature on an upcoming reality model TV series which will be aired nationally. A second batch will feature on this year’s award winning edition of Miss Glamorous 2016 - which will take place on the 17th December 2016. The winner will walk away with a sum of  Ksh.100,000 as well as a two night all expense paid trip to Zanzibar. The  1st runners up will also get a token Ksh. 40,000. Other contestants will not be left empty-handed as the will receive gift hampers, etiquette runway and basic fashion/modeling skills  compliment their long awaited journey to being Africa’s next top models. The event will happen at the Catholic University of East Africa (CUEA) along Langata road on the date stated above. For more information email; affrikmodels@afrikanasaha.co.ke Check out some of the contestants below:

item.title: Mi Casa's Stimulating House Element
item.dc:creator: nasaba
item.content:encoded: Before 'Jika', I know I had no idea who or what Mi Casa was. I am sure I came across some of their earlier tracks on YouTube, but I stubbornly glazed over them to listen to other tracks. But fast forward and they released this amazing track, I believe back in 2013, which got me hooked to their style of music. I would later play quite a few more tracks, but my issue was there wasn't enough tracks out there from the band. There something spectacular about South African house music. I think it's the percussion, the rhythm, the groovy way it moves you. It can also be the disco-reinvented sound that makes it fun to listen to. What I do know is that it's one genre we don't expect to lose its momentum anytime soon. I’ve always had a great appreciation for artists in today’s day and age who blend raw, beautiful instruments in their tracks. Mi Casa is one such group with great skill in music. So over the weekend, I got to attend the band's, fully-packed performance at Privee in Westlands, Nairobi. They had pulled such a massive crowd. The stage was set and an amazing Bassist, Carlo Jooste, joined the band to offer a thrilling show. I have always loved live performances, and this one was nothing short of . Well it wasn't my ideal kind of show, but I will give it a pass. From that display, I was able to conclude why Mi Casa is such an amazing band. The greatest weapon they have is the trumpet (don't get me wrong, bruh! This obsession has nothing to do with Trump). I think Mo-T does a brilliant job on the trumpet. Personally, I think he captures the best element of the bands sound. The trumpet does wonders to tracks. It oozes positivity. It is interesting. It has worked for so many other artists. Well I also wouldn't ignore the fact that J'Something exhibits soulful vocals and Dr. Duda is such an brilliant pianist. They also possess extraordinary song writing skills. There is a sense of simplicity in how they create their music, and with their strengths cohesively packaged you only wish to listen to them again and again. Until today, the joyous immediacy of discovering Mi Casa's music has not yet faded.

item.title: Music Could Be Your Best Friend
item.dc:creator: Kutswavictor
item.content:encoded: Inside the not so tiny space, beneath the beautiful "Makuti" roof of Tree House and this is where it all went down on the 4th of November. It was the  9th edition of Lovers & Friends. Catchy name, right? The event dubbed “For The Love of Music” saw a massive crowd attendance. There was a great sense of euphoria amidst the artists who were set to perform . The show provided  the perfect space to hang out with a couple of friends as you listen to music.  For the lovers of live music performances who weren’t there, I will boastfully say you missed out on this impressive show. For the hundreds who attended, I am sure they would agree with me that it was a magical experience. You never get to experience the actual intent of musical piece until you listen to it direct from the artist.  Artists expressed themselves in different music styles - ranging from rap, rhumba, benga, R&B and afro-soul.  In the brilliant line-up was Zeshari, Shantyl, CeeL & Luki, Le Band, The Kahawas, Willy Fololo with Melanin, Phy with guitarist Benjamin Kabasake and the actual stars of the show Meryl Paige and 125. The trio brought the place down after performing an exclusive rendition of their hit song "TAABU", a collabo with Red acapella. The set gave such a relaxed feel and at the same time we got to enjoy the live session from a number of upcoming artist. By the end of the show, everybody was so captivated that they didn’t want the show to end. They demanded for more, but unfortunately an artist understands that you ought to leave the crowd begging for more. If you want fans to keep coming, don't give them the entire package at once. I don't know if that really works. Anyway, if you missed out on this one, make sure you are not left out of the fun next time.   Photo Credits: Kutswa Imboto

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
This is really nice Nasaba, one detail though when will the next event be? I am looking forward to reading more of your articles.
PS: The photos are good.

Thank you, Selfine!
We will certainly keep you updated! Subscribe to get the latest stories!

item.title: Safaricom Jazz Lounge
item.dc:creator: nasaba
item.content:encoded: There are various variables people consider when picking an event to attend. There’s location, the artistes performing, the VIP experience, the art, the theme, the crowd and sometimes the sponsors. When it comes to modern-day concerts in Nairobi, none beats Safaricom Jazz Festival. The evening extravaganza attracts a large crowd (both young and old) of music enthusiasts from all over the country – along with our very own talented artistes. I would consider it a perfect spot to study a thing or two about world-class performance. So, Bob Collymore and his enabled team (specious and only because I really care about the music bit), managed to curate the enormously profitable show at Uhuru Gardens. Because of unavoidable reasons, I failed to get to the venue early enough to catch the start of the show (and I regret that). But again, I still got to witness the fascinating parts of the entire set. So Kenyan band Shamsi Music was already on stage when I arrived. The energy was up in the air. The band was a brilliant pick and certainly they did not fail their own. Their performance was exemplary. I actually can't get one of their songs out of my head.   Then there were the headlining acts: Cuban pianist Roberto Fonseca, his band and Malian Fatoumata Diawara. The ensemble came together to gift concertgoers with an electrifying show, one full of power. Fatoumata and Fonseca sang some really deep songs on poliitcal and social matters. Fatou sang on issues she been through like Female Genitalia Mutilation. More often than not, they got the crowd on their feet, chanting and singing along. Fonseca and the band showcased their brilliance on their instruments as the entire ensemble performed songs like “Sowa,” “Boloko” and “Bibisa.” Fatou, too, played her guitar with great skill. It was an event to celebrate great music, big ideas, big artists and cultural diversity. For the music lovers, it provided the perfect scene to escape and unwind. Here are more pictures from the performance... Photo Credits: Eugene Okumu

item.title: Otto von Bismarck
item.dc:creator: nasaba
item.content:encoded: A really great man is known by three signs: generosity in the design, humanity in the execution, moderation in the success.

item.title: The Market Hits The Streets
item.dc:creator: Kutswavictor
item.content:encoded: Fashion is what you buy, style is what you do with it. Style is about mixing designer clothes with thrift store finds. Style is about confidence and integrating ideas. Now the heavy rains are just around the corner, and, for this reason, I put together a simple way to dress and embrace the sun while it still shines. I kinda do my shopping in London, Paris, USA, Italy and Dubai, then pick it up from Nairobi's Gikomba Market.😂  All designer, bruh!😂 You might think of it's mere talk, good people, but Gikomba really works Magic. It's not really the best environment to shop, but you know they say "nothing worth having comes easy.' Anyway, I believe it is the most interesting stop for anyone with a great sense of style (but you also need to know your way around). The most interesting aspect about the market is that nobody goes there expecting to find a specific design. The market is about looking, finding and discovering. That means there's an enormous range of distinctive clad to choose from compared to that of a boutique selling replica designer attire. On one sunny day, I got to integrate various elements to get this amazing look. And it did not even cost much. Looking good, eeh? I know I do.     Also, I got to take pictures of one of the looks my boy Frank pulled. Frank was dressed in a white, mandarin collar shirt, purple Zara blazer, black slim-fit denim jeans and a pair of black swede shoes on. All these pieces acquired from Gikomba. His black Ray-Ban glasses completed the entire look. I can mention a good number of amazing people who get their looks from the market. I can also confirm to you that their fashion styles are quite eclectic and stunning. The market provides interesting clothes that not everybody else has. Clothes can also be a very remarkable form of expression for a creative mind. Experiment. Parting-shot: Always keep it sleek and you'll never disappoint. For me, fit is everything. Good Luck and Happy No-Shave November to all!

item.title: Jim Chuchu's "The Bones Remember" Exhibit
item.dc:creator: nasaba
item.content:encoded: I walked into an Exhibition set at the Goethe Institute and was completely pleased by what met my eyes. An incredible work of genius videography showed on the walls. There were a handful of people scattered about, with their eyes glued to the walls. You could actually tell how engaging the piece of work was as the audience keenly stared. I had previously heard a lot about the amazing Chuchu, but I had never really put a face to the name. I thought I was told embellished stories about his work, but in true sense he is a prodigy. Well this was indeed an amazing opportunity to witness his work, and it actually turned out to be very, very captivating. So six projection simultaneously shown onto the walls. The show featured five of Chuchu's monochromatic creations: Invocation: The Severance of Ties ( 2015 ), Invocation: Release ( 2015 ), Juu Chini ( 2016 ), Duara ( 2016 ) and Tuli ( 2016 ). It could be assumed that Chuchu's defiance to conform with the conventional norms could have inspired his work. He has been termed controversial, he is gay and has also had his LGBT film banned by the Kenya Film and Classification Board. For those viewing Chuchu's creations in the gallery, there's is a mystery - and beauty- that builds when he expresses an uncompromised African Spirituality. While our own experiences influence how we perceive his work, the exhibition leaves you asking serious question about the existence as Africans. The videos show African people taking part in mystic, non-Christian,yogic rituals. This was a display intended to kindle the thought of believing that things would be very different if imperialism wasn't as rife as it. The white man colonized the unaware Africans and it is that way that he was able to impose his disruptive beliefs on us Africans. And because of that there has been a almost   The exhibition, however, tried to escape this idea and try to showcase an Africa that stuck to its spiritual ways     In this exhibition, Chuchu teases out the consequences of colonialism on the African Spirituality. Somehow he advocates for an anti-imperialistic society or he simply just wants to imagine a world where we didn't have to conform to the imperialists ways. Either way, the exhibit was really impressive.

item.title: To Beard or Not To Beard
item.dc:creator: Kutswavictor
item.content:encoded:
These days, everything seems like a fad, but when an otherwise ridiculous idea is attached to a good cause, then it is something that is worthy of support. November is a well-known time of the year when the world's men get into a frenzy of not shaving their beards, some out of fun - and the rest to help raise awareness about male health. Just like other days that are marked annually to draw attention to specified targets of awareness, No-Shave November is one that I particularly do not mind others from practicing it just for a passing moment. I am a Sikh and in our faith, the keeping of unshorn hair is part of our identity which has its deeply connected spiritual reasons. In that respect, all practicing Sikhs are pro-male-health all year round, and not just for a handful of days. Beards are a sign of manliness and also of spirituality. These days, everything seems like a fad, but when an otherwise ridiculous idea is attached to a good cause, then it is something that is worthy of support. November is a well-known time of the year when the world's men get into a frenzy of not shaving their beards, some out of fun - and the rest to help raise awareness about male health. Just like other days that are marked annually to draw attention to specified targets of awareness, No-Shave November is one that I particularly do not mind others from practicing it just for a passing moment. I am a Sikh and in our faith, the keeping of unshorn hair is part of our identity which has its deeply connected spiritual reasons. In that respect, all practicing Sikhs are pro-male-health all year round, and not just for a handful of days. Beards are a sign of manliness and also of spirituality. Ever noticed why holy men of the past - and even in the present - maintained long tresses and beards? Look at the illustrations in and even mentions of it in the Bible and Quran. Back then, it was regarded as the very image of God - long, uncut tresses and a flowing beard. Jesus himself is depicted with such a hallowed image. That is exactly how Sikhs men live out their faith - beautiful, uncut, well-maintained beards; long tresses tied into a know on the head and dressed daily with a crown-like turban. This is how i maintain my outward identity - a reflection and reminder of my spiritual obligations, responsibility and love for how God created us to be.  This very image is that of being saintly, humble and wise. These are the basic values others will expect of us and also inspire into them - and become beacons of hope on how to live an ideal life dedicated to the principles of faith. Besides the Sikhs, there are also others who also maintain long, flowing beards, if not the tresses. The Jews, Rastafarians and Muslims also keep beards as a symbol and reminder of divinity, courage and manliness. That is why the beard is not just a passing fancy for others, as it is to the rest. But while it may be an option for other religions, it is not for Sikhs for Sikhs are Saint-Soldiers in identity, where the outward is a proof and reminder of the inner values. Nevertheless, if it helps to bring proven benefit to those in genuine need, then it doesn't matter whether we keep beards for faith or for causes - just be true to your own ideals and principles and the world will notice without your even uttering a word. 'But for one who is a man to comb himself and shave himself with a razor, for the sake of fine effect, to arrange his hair at the looking-glass, to shave his cheeks, pluck hairs out of them, and smooth them, how womanly! And, in truth, unless you saw them naked, you would suppose them to be women.' ~ St. Clement of Alexandria
So, the next time you think keeping a beard is just a game, remember Samson of the Bible and what he lost when his tresses and beard got done away with. There is great power in the beard and tresses. We all need to realise it to experience it.
Ever noticed why holy men of the past - and even in the present - maintained long tresses and beards? Look at the illustrations in and even mentions of it in the Bible and Quran. Back then, it was regarded as the very image of God - long, uncut tresses and a flowing beard. Jesus himself is depicted with such a hallowed image. That is exactly how Sikhs men live out their faith - beautiful, uncut, well-maintained beards; long tresses tied into a know on the head and dressed daily with a crown-like turban. This is how i maintain my outward identity - a reflection and reminder of my spiritual obligations, responsibility and love for how God created us to be.  This very image is that of being saintly, humble and wise. These are the basic values others will expect of us and also inspire into them - and become beacons of hope on how to live an ideal life dedicated to the principles of faith. Besides the Sikhs, there are also others who also maintain long, flowing beards, if not the tresses. The Jews, Rastafarians and Muslims also keep beards as a symbol and reminder of divinity, courage and manliness. That is why the beard is not just a passing fancy for others, as it is to the rest. But while it may be an option for other religions, it is not for Sikhs for Sikhs are Saint-Soldiers in identity, where the outward is a proof and reminder of the inner values. Nevertheless, if it helps to bring proven benefit to those in genuine need, then it doesn't matter whether we keep beards for faith or for causes - just be true to your own ideals and principles and the world will notice without your even uttering a word. 'But for one who is a man to comb himself and shave himself with a razor, for the sake of fine effect, to arrange his hair at the looking-glass, to shave his cheeks, pluck hairs out of them, and smooth them, how womanly! And, in truth, unless you saw them naked, you would suppose them to be women.' ~ St. Clement of Alexandria
So, the next time you think keeping a beard is just a game, remember Samson of the Bible and what he lost when his tresses and beard got done away with. There is great power in the beard and tresses. We all need to realise it to experience it.
